isis.stitle: TSI 03-04-01 - New Hydraulic Disc Brake Slide Pins, Bolts, and Lubricant

subjectgroup.subject: New Hydraulic Disc Brake Slide Pins, Bolts, and Lubricant

geninfo.para: Effective June 3, 2002, all International Hydraulic Disc Brake vehicles began using a newly designed caliper mounting slide pin and bolt configuration. The new slide pins and bolts are compatible with previous production Pin Slide Brakes but have the following physical differences: The new design uses fine thread, flanged head patch bolts which must be torqued to 100 ft./lbs., not 75 ft./lbs. and, as with the previous design, the leading pin should still be torqued first. Once the new design patch bolts have been removed, the thread area should be buffed with a wire brush to remove any Loctite buildup, and then a single stripe of Loctite 2440 must be applied to the threads before reusing. The leading and trailing slide pins are no longer interchangeable because the trailing pin now has a notched head and a rubber bushing on the pin diameter (See Bosch ZOH-T Anchor Plate Repair Kits Installation Procedure below). When servicing hydraulic Pin Slide Disc Brakes, International recommends that the slide pins and bolts be updated to the latest generation slide pins and bolts and that the existing lubricant be cleaned from the pins and bores and replaced with improved lubricant 2585384C1. It is important that the slide pins and bolts not be mixed on the same axle. Both wheels on each axle must have the same type slide pins and bolts. Order one Slide Pin and Bolt Repair Kit per wheel.
The Bosch Technical Summary below describes the component and assembly torque changes.

svcproc.title: Bosch ZOH-T Anchor Plate Repair Kit Installation Procedure

svcprocinfo.para: IMPORTANT NOTE: Because the two ZOH-T caliper pins are different from each other, and it is important that they are installed in the correct anchor plate location. The following diagrams show how to determine leading vs. trailing pin location for correctly installing ZOH-T guide pins. Definition of anchor plate LEADING and TRAILING position: Imagine a point on the outboard surface of the rotor on the opposite side from the caliper. Now rotate the rotor as if the vehicle were moving in the forward direction. The FIRST mounting pin that this point passes is the LEADING position. The other is the TRAILING position.

para.title: ZOH-T Caliper Mounting Bolt Styles After June 3, 2002

svcsubproc.title: Anchor Plate Service Repair Kit Installation Procedure
svcsubproc.para: INFORMATION - The anchor plate assembly includes lubricated floating guide pins sealed by rubber boots and stainless steel slippers which protect the anchor plate pad abutments. A tie bar is used on 2x73 mm pin slide disc brake only. A 2x66mm pin slide disc brake does not have a tie bar and will have shorter bolts to plug the threaded holes used to mount the tie bar.

item.para: Prior to June 3, 2002, the ZOPS caliper mounting guide pins were the same and used a M12x1.75x30mm course thread and heavy hex-head mounting bolt with an installation torque of 75+/-5 ft-lbs.

After June 3, 2002, ZOH-T caliper mounting guide pins are different between the leading and trailing anchor plate locations. The separate pieces (guide pins and bolts) are NOT individually interchangeable or backward compatible between the ZOPS and ZOH-T caliper designs. This is because the mounting threads have been changed from coarse (M12x1.75mm) to fine (M12x1.25mm). Also, the ZOH-T bolt is a longer (40mm) flange-head style vs the ZOPS bolt which is a shorter (30mm) heavy hex-head style.

When servicing the guide pins manufactured prior to June 3, 2002 (i.e. the original ZOPS caliper design), it is permissible to use the ZOH-T pins and bolts as long as they are changed as a set.
However, since the ZOH-T pins are now different, it is VERY IMPORTANT that they are installed in the correct anchor plate bore position as shown on the proceeding diagram. The leading pin must be installed in the leading anchor plate location, and the rubber bushed trailing pin must be installed in the trailing anchor plate location.
You MUST use the correct bolt AND mounting torque with the correct pin hardware level during servicing.

svcsubproc.title: Anchor Plate Assembly Repair Kit - Service Procedure

step1.para: Position vehicle on suitable floor stands and remove wheel (tire and rim).

warning.para: A jack must never be used alone to support a vehicle while under-chassis service is being performed. The jack may lower and serious personal injury could result. Always support vehicle with suitable floor stands.

step1.para: Remove the brake hose retaining bolt attached to the caliper housing. This will allow easier caliper removal and installation. (Not required on all applications)
Remove lower (bottom) caliper mounting bolt securing the caliper to the anchor plate.
Remove upper (top) caliper mounting bolt securing the caliper to the anchor plate.

Move caliper assembly away from rotor and place it in a secure location on the vehicle suspension. Secure the caliper assembly with a tie wrap in place so that it does not fall. Be sure brake hose or line is not kinked and does not support the weight of the caliper.
Remove inboard and outboard disc brake pads from anchor plate pad abutment slippers.

Check machined surfaces of caliper ears. If any rust or contaminants are present, use a hand held wire brush to clean these surfaces. If any grease or oil is present, use solvent on a clean shop cloth to remove it.

note.para: It is important to clean those areas of the caliper, guide pins and anchor plate that are in contact with the brake pads or each other.

step1.para: Visually inspect caliper for leakage, damage or defects to piston boots or pistons. If leakage or damage is found, repair or replace as required.

Visually inspect anchor plate for damage or defects to mating surfaces and at anchor plate pad abutment slippers. IF NO damage is found, continue with step 11. If damage is found, remove anchor plate and replace with ANCHOR PLATE REPLACEMENT KIT. Install anchor plate replacement kit and move to step 19.
Remove and discard caliper guide pins, guide pin boots and caliper mounting bolts.
IMPORTANT NOTE: See "Information" section regarding pin differences between the ZOPS and ZOH-T caliper designs.

caution.para: DO NOT cut, grind or modify in any way, the guide pins or vehicle components when attempting guide pin removal or installation. Brake assembly or component functional degradation may occur if altered in any way. If ample clearance does not exist to remove and install the caliper guide pins, then removal of the anchor plate is necessary for proper guide pin service. Refer to service manual for anchor plate removal and installation.

step1.para: Loosen the anchor plate tie bar bolts that are opposite the caliper guide pins. (ONLY ON 2X73 CALIPER ASSEMBLIES). This will aid in the new guide pin installation.
Visually inspect anchor plate guide pin bores for rust or contamination. If contamination is found, clean anchor plate guide pin bores with wire brush and solvent. Dry with compressed air.
Lightly lubricate guide pin boot ridges with a thin film of Albida PPS1 Grease provided in packets contained in the service kit.
Install guide pin boots onto both leading and trailing pins.
Completely grease anchor plate guide pin bore surfaces with Albida PPS1 Grease provided in packets contained in the service kit.
Completely grease the leading and trailing guide pins with Albida PPS1 Grease provided in packets contained in the service kit.
Install leading pin into anchor plate leading position.
IMPORTANT NOTE: See diagram for determining "leading" position.
Install rubber bushed trailing pin into the anchor plate trailing position.
IMPORTANT NOTE: See diagram for determining the "trailing" position.
Make sure that the guide pin heads, mounting bolts, and mating caliper surfaces are clean of any grease or foreign matter. Use clean shop cloth and solvent to remove foreign debris.
IMPORTANT NOTE: Do not allow cleaning solvent to come into contact with guide pin boots.
Reinstall inner and outer pads onto the anchor plate abutments.

note.para: If re-using caliper mounting bolts, See "Caliper Mounting Preparation Procedure" in Appendix A before proceeding with step 21.

step1.para: Align flat on upper (top) guide pin head with the flat on caliper upper (top) guide pin boss. Be careful when positioning caliper over the disc brake pads, rotor and upper (top) guide pin head to avoid tearing, cutting or dislodging piston boots or guide pin boots.
Install upper (top) flange head mounting bolt FINGER tight securing the caliper to the anchor plate.
Align the flat on the lower pin flange and then carefully rotate the caliper closed and install lower mounting bolt FINGER tight. Do not allow the brake line hose to become pinched or kinked.

note.para: Always tighten the leading caliper mounting bolt first.

step1.para: Tighten the leading ZOH-T caliper mounting bolt to 93 - 107 ft-lbs. (126 - 145 N-m).
Tighten the trailing ZOH-T caliper mounting bolt to 93 - 107 ft-lbs. (126 - 145 N-m).

para.emph: Reminder: If either caliper mounting bolt has been loosened, it is important to tighten the mounting bolts in the proper sequence shown in steps 24 and 25. Increased brake drag may result from not tightening in proper sequence.

step1.para: Reinstall brake hose retaining clip bolt and torque to manufacturer service manual specifications.
Tighten anchor plate tie bar bolts. Torque to 40-50 ft-lb (54-68 N-m).
Reinstall wheel (tire and rim) on vehicle and torque wheel attachment nuts per vehicle manufacturer recommendation. Remove floor stands.

Before starting engine, depress brake pedal several times to reseat the brake pads to the rotor. Check the master cylinder reservoir and fill if necessary. Consult service manual for proper brake fluid.
After brake service, be sure to test brakes prior to returning vehicle into service to ensure a firm pedal during brake application.

svcsubproc.title: APPENDIX A: Recommended Procedure for Re-using the Caliper Mounting Bolts

step1.para: Visually inspect the removed bolts for any thread damage, contamination, or corrosion. If damaged replace.

Visually inspect the caliper mounting bolts for a white/yellow residue resulting from a previously applied Loctite adhesive patch, as shown in Figure 4. If no patch appears skip Step 3 and continue on to Step 4.

figure.caption: Figure 4. Used Caliper Mounting Bolt with Adhesive Patch on the Threads

step1.para: Using a steel brush buff the adhesive residue from the bolt threads, as shown in Figure 5. Buff ONLY the area where the adhesive is present so as not to remove the protective black coating on the remainder of the threads. Be sure to completely remove the existing adhesive so that bare steel is now showing where the adhesive once was, as shown in Figure 6.

figure.caption: Figure 5. Use A Steel Brush To Buff Away Existing Adhesive Residue
Figure 6. Once Adhesive Is Removed A Clean Shiny Steel Surface Should Remain

step1.para: Apply a small patch of liquid Loctite 2440 to the area indicated in Figure 4. For best Loctite 2440 performance, surfaces should be clean and free of grease. Product should be applied to the bolt in sufficient quantity to fill all engaged threads; develops useable strength within 1 hour and full strength at room temperature in 3 hours.

figure.caption: Figure 7. Liquid Loctite 2440 Applied to Clean Threads for Reinstallation

svcsubproc.para: Return to Step 21 of Anchor plate Repair Procedure above.
